items.title: FBI raids home and seizes devices of Washington Post journalist
items.description: The reporter had previously reported on the Trump administration's efforts to fire hundreds of thousands of federal workers.

items.title: Chinese scientists develop 'soggy sand' battery that lasts 1,700 cycles

featured_image.name: The Surprising Battery Discovery No One Saw Coming

items.description:
Scientists at the Dalian Institute of Chemical Physics (DICP) of the Chinese Academy of Sciences have developed a novel "soggy sand" electrolyte that enables aqueous zinc metal batteries to achieve 1,700 charge-discharge cycles while operating at temperatures up to 140°C—a breakthrough that could accelerate the shift away from lithium-ion technology for grid-scale energy storage.

The research, published in Nature Communications in December 2025, addresses one of the most persistent challenges facing aqueous zinc batteries: their tendency to fail under thermal stress due to uncontrollable side reactions in traditional water-based electrolytes above 60°C.[1][2][3][4]

items.title: Some US personnel told to leave largest Middle East base in Qatar

featured_image.name: Some personnel were advised to leave U.S. military base in Qatar, diplomats tell Reuters

items.description:
Some personnel at the U.S. military's Al Udeid Air Base in Qatar were advised to leave by Wednesday evening, according to three diplomats who spoke to Reuters, raising concerns about possible military action against Iran amid escalating tensions between Washington and Tehran.[1][2]

The U.S. Embassy in Doha has not provided an immediate comment on the advisory. Al Udeid serves as the largest American military installation in the Middle East, accommodating approximately 10,000 service members. A similar precautionary evacuation occurred ahead of U.S. airstrikes on Iran's nuclear facilities in June 2025, when personnel were moved off U.S. bases in the region before Iran launched retaliatory missile strikes on the base.[3][4][2][1]

items.title: Global markets await U.S. inflation report

featured_image.name: Stock futures lose ground as traders weigh more bank earnings

items.description:
Markets across Asia and Europe mostly advanced on Wednesday as investors awaited U.S. producer price and retail sales data, while Wall Street futures slipped ahead of another round of major bank earnings.

Japan's benchmark Nikkei 225 surged 1.5% to 54,341.23, extending a record-breaking rally fueled by speculation that Prime Minister Sanae Takaichi may call early elections. The broader Topix also climbed to new highs. Elsewhere in Asia, Hong Kong's Hang Seng added 0.6% to 26,999.81, while China's Shanghai Composite shed 0.3% to 4,126.09.[1][2][3]

items.title: X to change AI chatbot after outrage over sexual deepfake images
items.description: New laws in the UK that would outlaw the generation of sexual deepfakes are set to come into force this week.

items.title: Scientists open ice sanctuary in Antarctica to preserve melting glaciers
items.description:
Researchers sealed ancient glacial ice from the European Alps in a purpose-built cave at Antarctica's Concordia Station on Wednesday, inaugurating the world's first sanctuary designed to preserve climate records from melting glaciers for centuries to come.

The Ice Memory Foundation placed its first two ice cores, extracted from Grand Combin glacier in Switzerland and Mont Blanc in France, into a 35-meter-long cave dug approximately 10 meters below the Antarctic surface, where temperatures remain stable at minus 52 degrees Celsius year-round without any need for artificial refrigeration.[1][2][3]

"To safeguard what would be otherwise irreversibly lost... is an endeavour for humanity," said Thomas Stocker, a Swiss climate scientist and chair of the Ice Memory Foundation, which spearheaded the initiative.[4][1]

items.title: China installs world's largest offshore wind turbine

featured_image.name: World's first megawatt-level airborne 'windmill' feeds power ...

items.description: China has reached two notable advances in wind energy within the span of a week, successfully testing the world's first megawatt-class airborne wind power system and installing a record-breaking 20-megawatt offshore turbine.

items.title: Toyota raises buyout bid 15% after Elliott pressure

featured_image.name: Elliott heaps pressure on Toyota with 5% stake in group firm slated ...

items.description:
Toyota Motor announced Wednesday it has increased its bid to take Toyota Industries private to ¥18,800 per share, up 15% from the original ¥16,300 offer made in June, caving to pressure from activist investor Elliott Investment Management.

The revised tender offer, set to begin Thursday and run through February 12, values the forklift manufacturer at approximately ¥5.6 trillion ($35 billion). The increase represents a win for shareholder activism in Japan, where no entity has previously challenged a company of Toyota's magnitude.[1][2]

items.title: Iran judiciary signals fast executions for protesters
items.description: The comments from Iran's judiciary chief come as activists warn that protesters detained during demonstrations in Iran could soon be hanged.

items.title: China's car exports topped 7 million in 2025 as EV sales boomed

featured_image.name: China car sales may stagnate in 2026, strong EV export ...

items.description:
China's automobile exports surged 21 percent in 2025 to exceed 7 million vehicles, propelled by booming overseas shipments of electric vehicles even as demand at home showed signs of strain, the China Association of Automobile Manufacturers reported Wednesday.[1][2][3]

The figures underscore a pivotal shift for the world's largest automotive market: Chinese automakers are increasingly looking abroad for growth as fierce domestic price wars and waning consumer confidence weigh on local sales. Exports of new energy vehicles, including battery-electric and plug-in hybrid models, doubled from the previous year to reach 2.6 million units.[4][3][5]

items.title: Scientists question studies claiming microplastics in human brains

featured_image.name: Are microplastics harmful to our health? Scientists are ...

items.description:
Prominent research claiming microplastics have infiltrated human brains, arteries, and organs is facing serious scrutiny, with analytical chemists warning that many findings may be artifacts of contamination and false positives rather than actual plastic particles.

The controversy, reported by The Guardian this week, has cast doubt on a body of research that had fueled growing public alarm about the health effects of plastic pollution. Seven studies have now been formally challenged by researchers publishing criticism in the same journals where the original papers appeared, while a recent analysis flagged 18 additional studies for allegedly failing to account for human tissue producing measurements easily confused with common plastics.[1][2][3]

items.title: Captured tobacco kingpin thought 'he was out of reach', says Burke
items.description: Home Affairs Minister Tony Burke says he believes tobacco kingpin Kaz Hamad thought he was "out of reach" of authorities before his arrest in Iraq.

items.title: Fungal network researcher wins 'Nobel Prize for Environment'
items.description:
Evolutionary biologist Toby Kiers has won the 2026 Tyler Prize for Environmental Achievement, often called the "Nobel Prize for Environment," for her research into underground fungal networks that play a crucial role in regulating Earth's climate.[1][2][3]

The Tyler Prize Executive Committee announced Tuesday that Kiers, a professor at Vrije Universiteit Amsterdam, is being honored for her "transformative research on the significance of mycorrhizal fungi in underground transfers, biodiversity, and climate resilience." She is the youngest female recipient in the prize's history and will receive the $250,000 award at a ceremony in Amsterdam on April 23.[2][1]

items.title: Hackers access student emails, passwords in major school data breach
items.description: Hackers have accessed the emails, passwords and names of past and present students from all Victorian government schools in a major data breach.
